Chapter IV. Congratulatory
From the dimly-lighted passages of the court,

9.text:
the last sediment of the human stew that had
been boiling there all day, was straining

15.text:
off, when Doctor Manette, Lucie Manette, his
daughter, Mr. Lorry, the solicitor for the

21.text:
defence, and its counsel, Mr. Stryver, stood
gathered round Mr. Charles Darnay—just released—congratulating

29.text:
him on his escape from death.
It would have been difficult by a far brighter

34.text:
light, to recognise in Doctor Manette, intellectual
of face and upright of bearing, the shoemaker

41.text:
of the garret in Paris. Yet, no one could
have looked at him twice, without looking

47.text:
again: even though the opportunity of observation
had not extended to the mournful cadence of

53.text:
his low grave voice, and to the abstraction
that overclouded him fitfully, without any

59.text:
apparent reason. While one external cause,
and that a reference to his long lingering

65.text:
agony, would always—as on the trial—evoke
this condition from the depths of his soul,

71.text:
it was also in its nature to arise of itself,
and to draw a gloom over him, as incomprehensible

78.text:
to those unacquainted with his story as if
they had seen the shadow of the actual Bastille

84.text:
thrown upon him by a summer sun, when the
substance was three hundred miles away.

91.text:
Only his daughter had the power of charming
this black brooding from his mind. She was

96.text:
the golden thread that united him to a Past
beyond his misery, and to a Present beyond

103.text:
his misery: and the sound of her voice, the
light of her face, the touch of her hand,

108.text:
had a strong beneficial influence with him
almost always. Not absolutely always, for

115.text:
she could recall some occasions on which her
power had failed; but they were few and slight,

121.text:
and she believed them over.
Mr. Darnay had kissed her hand fervently and

128.text:
gratefully, and had turned to Mr. Stryver,
whom he warmly thanked. Mr. Stryver, a man

134.text:
of little more than thirty, but looking twenty
years older than he was, stout, loud, red,

140.text:
bluff, and free from any drawback of delicacy,
had a pushing way of shouldering himself (morally

148.text:
and physically) into companies and conversations,
that argued well for his shouldering his way

154.text:
up in life.
He still had his wig and gown on, and he said,

160.text:
squaring himself at his late client to that
degree that he squeezed the innocent Mr. Lorry

165.text:
clean out of the group: "I am glad to have
brought you off with honour, Mr. Darnay. It

170.text:
was an infamous prosecution, grossly infamous;
but not the less likely to succeed on that

176.text:
account."
"You have laid me under an obligation to you

180.text:
for life—in two senses," said his late client,
taking his hand.

185.text:
"I have done my best for you, Mr. Darnay;
and my best is as good as another man's, I

190.text:
believe."
It clearly being incumbent on some one to

194.text:
say, "Much better," Mr. Lorry said it; perhaps
not quite disinterestedly, but with the interested

201.text:
object of squeezing himself back again.
"You think so?" said Mr. Stryver. "Well! you

208.text:
have been present all day, and you ought to
know. You are a man of business, too."

212.text:
"And as such," quoth Mr. Lorry, whom the counsel
learned in the law had now shouldered back

218.text:
into the group, just as he had previously
shouldered him out of it—"as such I will

224.text:
appeal to Doctor Manette, to break up this
conference and order us all to our homes.

229.text:
Miss Lucie looks ill, Mr. Darnay has had a
terrible day, we are worn out."

235.text:
"Speak for yourself, Mr. Lorry," said Stryver;
"I have a night's work to do yet. Speak for

241.text:
yourself."
"I speak for myself," answered Mr. Lorry,

245.text:
"and for Mr. Darnay, and for Miss Lucie, and—Miss
Lucie, do you not think I may speak for us

252.text:
all?" He asked her the question pointedly,
and with a glance at her father.

257.text:
His face had become frozen, as it were, in
a very curious look at Darnay: an intent look,

265.text:
deepening into a frown of dislike and distrust,
not even unmixed with fear. With this strange

271.text:
expression on him his thoughts had wandered
away.

275.text:
"My father," said Lucie, softly laying her
hand on his.

280.text:
He slowly shook the shadow off, and turned
to her.

283.text:
"Shall we go home, my father?"
With a long breath, he answered "Yes."

292.text:
The friends of the acquitted prisoner had
dispersed, under the impression—which he

297.text:
himself had originated—that he would not
be released that night. The lights were nearly

302.text:
all extinguished in the passages, the iron
gates were being closed with a jar and a rattle,

308.text:
and the dismal place was deserted until to-morrow
morning's interest of gallows, pillory, whipping-post,

315.text:
and branding-iron, should repeople it. Walking
between her father and Mr. Darnay, Lucie Manette

323.text:
passed into the open air. A hackney-coach
was called, and the father and daughter departed

328.text:
in it.
Mr. Stryver had left them in the passages,

332.text:
to shoulder his way back to the robing-room.
Another person, who had not joined the group,

338.text:
or interchanged a word with any one of them,
but who had been leaning against the wall

342.text:
where its shadow was darkest, had silently
strolled out after the rest, and had looked

348.text:
on until the coach drove away. He now stepped
up to where Mr. Lorry and Mr. Darnay stood

355.text:
upon the pavement.
"So, Mr. Lorry! Men of business may speak

359.text:
to Mr. Darnay now?"
Nobody had made any acknowledgment of Mr.

364.text:
Carton's part in the day's proceedings; nobody
had known of it. He was unrobed, and was none

370.text:
the better for it in appearance.
"If you knew what a conflict goes on in the

375.text:
business mind, when the business mind is divided
between good-natured impulse and business

381.text:
appearances, you would be amused, Mr. Darnay."
Mr. Lorry reddened, and said, warmly, "You

388.text:
have mentioned that before, sir. We men of
business, who serve a House, are not our own

394.text:
masters. We have to think of the House more
than ourselves."

397.text:
"_I_ know, _I_ know," rejoined Mr. Carton,
carelessly. "Don't be nettled, Mr. Lorry.

403.text:
You are as good as another, I have no doubt:
better, I dare say."

407.text:
"And indeed, sir," pursued Mr. Lorry, not
minding him, "I really don't know what you

413.text:
have to do with the matter. If you'll excuse
me, as very much your elder, for saying so,

418.text:
I really don't know that it is your business."
"Business! Bless you, _I_ have no business,"

424.text:
said Mr. Carton.
"It is a pity you have not, sir."

428.text:
"I think so, too."
"If you had," pursued Mr. Lorry, "perhaps

432.text:
you would attend to it."
"Lord love you, no!—I shouldn't," said Mr.

437.text:
Carton.
"Well, sir!" cried Mr. Lorry, thoroughly heated

441.text:
by his indifference, "business is a very good
thing, and a very respectable thing. And,

447.text:
sir, if business imposes its restraints and
its silences and impediments, Mr. Darnay as

453.text:
a young gentleman of generosity knows how
to make allowance for that circumstance. Mr.

459.text:
Darnay, good night, God bless you, sir! I
hope you have been this day preserved for

464.text:
a prosperous and happy life.—Chair there!"
Perhaps a little angry with himself, as well

470.text:
as with the barrister, Mr. Lorry bustled into
the chair, and was carried off to Tellson's.

476.text:
Carton, who smelt of port wine, and did not
appear to be quite sober, laughed then, and

483.text:
turned to Darnay:
"This is a strange chance that throws you

487.text:
and me together. This must be a strange night
to you, standing alone here with your counterpart

492.text:
on these street stones?"
"I hardly seem yet," returned Charles Darnay,

498.text:
"to belong to this world again."
"I don't wonder at it; it's not so long since

503.text:
you were pretty far advanced on your way to
another. You speak faintly."

507.text:
"I begin to think I _am_ faint."
"Then why the devil don't you dine? I dined,

515.text:
myself, while those numskulls were deliberating
which world you should belong to—this, or

521.text:
some other. Let me show you the nearest tavern
to dine well at."

525.text:
Drawing his arm through his own, he took him
down Ludgate-hill to Fleet-street, and so,

531.text:
up a covered way, into a tavern. Here, they
were shown into a little room, where Charles

537.text:
Darnay was soon recruiting his strength with
a good plain dinner and good wine: while Carton

543.text:
sat opposite to him at the same table, with
his separate bottle of port before him, and

548.text:
his fully half-insolent manner upon him.
"Do you feel, yet, that you belong to this

554.text:
terrestrial scheme again, Mr. Darnay?"
"I am frightfully confused regarding time

560.text:
and place; but I am so far mended as to feel
that."

563.text:
"It must be an immense satisfaction!"
He said it bitterly, and filled up his glass

570.text:
again: which was a large one.
"As to me, the greatest desire I have, is

575.text:
to forget that I belong to it. It has no good
in it for me—except wine like this—nor

581.text:
I for it. So we are not much alike in that
particular. Indeed, I begin to think we are

587.text:
not much alike in any particular, you and
I."

592.text:
Confused by the emotion of the day, and feeling
his being there with this Double of coarse

597.text:
deportment, to be like a dream, Charles Darnay
was at a loss how to answer; finally, answered

604.text:
not at all.
"Now your dinner is done," Carton presently

608.text:
said, "why don't you call a health, Mr. Darnay;
why don't you give your toast?"

613.text:
"What health? What toast?"
"Why, it's on the tip of your tongue. It ought

618.text:
to be, it must be, I'll swear it's there."
"Miss Manette, then!"

624.text:
"Miss Manette, then!"
Looking his companion full in the face while

628.text:
he drank the toast, Carton flung his glass
over his shoulder against the wall, where

634.text:
it shivered to pieces; then, rang the bell,
and ordered in another.

639.text:
"That's a fair young lady to hand to a coach
in the dark, Mr. Darnay!" he said, filling

645.text:
his new goblet.
A slight frown and a laconic "Yes," were the

652.text:
answer.
"That's a fair young lady to be pitied by

656.text:
and wept for by! How does it feel? Is it worth
being tried for one's life, to be the object

662.text:
of such sympathy and compassion, Mr. Darnay?"
Again Darnay answered not a word.

669.text:
"She was mightily pleased to have your message,
when I gave it her. Not that she showed she

674.text:
was pleased, but I suppose she was."
The allusion served as a timely reminder to

680.text:
Darnay that this disagreeable companion had,
of his own free will, assisted him in the

687.text:
strait of the day. He turned the dialogue
to that point, and thanked him for it.

692.text:
"I neither want any thanks, nor merit any,"
was the careless rejoinder. "It was nothing

698.text:
to do, in the first place; and I don't know
why I did it, in the second. Mr. Darnay, let

704.text:
me ask you a question."
"Willingly, and a small return for your good

709.text:
offices."
"Do you think I particularly like you?"

713.text:
"Really, Mr. Carton," returned the other,
oddly disconcerted, "I have not asked myself

718.text:
the question."
"But ask yourself the question now."

722.text:
"You have acted as if you do; but I don't
think you do."

726.text:
"_I_ don't think I do," said Carton. "I begin
to have a very good opinion of your understanding."

732.text:
"Nevertheless," pursued Darnay, rising to
ring the bell, "there is nothing in that,

738.text:
I hope, to prevent my calling the reckoning,
and our parting without ill-blood on either

743.text:
side."
Carton rejoining, "Nothing in life!" Darnay

748.text:
rang. "Do you call the whole reckoning?" said
Carton. On his answering in the affirmative,

754.text:
"Then bring me another pint of this same wine,
drawer, and come and wake me at ten."

760.text:
The bill being paid, Charles Darnay rose and
wished him good night. Without returning the

766.text:
wish, Carton rose too, with something of a
threat of defiance in his manner, and said,

772.text:
"A last word, Mr. Darnay: you think I am drunk?"
"I think you have been drinking, Mr. Carton."

779.text:
"Think? You know I have been drinking."
"Since I must say so, I know it."

784.text:
"Then you shall likewise know why. I am a
disappointed drudge, sir. I care for no man

791.text:
on earth, and no man on earth cares for me."
"Much to be regretted. You might have used

797.text:
your talents better."
"May be so, Mr. Darnay; may be not. Don't

802.text:
let your sober face elate you, however; you
don't know what it may come to. Good night!"

810.text:
When he was left alone, this strange being
took up a candle, went to a glass that hung

815.text:
against the wall, and surveyed himself minutely
in it.

819.text:
"Do you particularly like the man?" he muttered,
at his own image; "why should you particularly

825.text:
like a man who resembles you? There is nothing
in you to like; you know that. Ah, confound

831.text:
you! What a change you have made in yourself!
A good reason for taking to a man, that he

836.text:
shows you what you have fallen away from,
and what you might have been! Change places

841.text:
with him, and would you have been looked at
by those blue eyes as he was, and commiserated

846.text:
by that agitated face as he was? Come on,
and have it out in plain words! You hate the

852.text:
fellow."
He resorted to his pint of wine for consolation,

857.text:
drank it all in a few minutes, and fell asleep
on his arms, with his hair straggling over

862.text:
the table, and a long winding-sheet in the
candle dripping down upon him.

877.text:
Chapter V. The Jackal
Those were drinking days, and most men drank

884.text:
hard. So very great is the improvement Time
has brought about in such habits, that a moderate

891.text:
statement of the quantity of wine and punch
which one man would swallow in the course

895.text:
of a night, without any detriment to his reputation
as a perfect gentleman, would seem, in these

901.text:
days, a ridiculous exaggeration. The learned
profession of the law was certainly not behind

908.text:
any other learned profession in its Bacchanalian
propensities; neither was Mr. Stryver, already

915.text:
fast shouldering his way to a large and lucrative
practice, behind his compeers in this particular,

922.text:
any more than in the drier parts of the legal
race.

925.text:
A favourite at the Old Bailey, and eke at
the Sessions, Mr. Stryver had begun cautiously

932.text:
to hew away the lower staves of the ladder
on which he mounted. Sessions and Old Bailey

939.text:
had now to summon their favourite, specially,
to their longing arms; and shouldering itself

945.text:
towards the visage of the Lord Chief Justice
in the Court of King's Bench, the florid countenance

951.text:
of Mr. Stryver might be daily seen, bursting
out of the bed of wigs, like a great sunflower

958.text:
pushing its way at the sun from among a rank
garden-full of flaring companions.

965.text:
It had once been noted at the Bar, that while
Mr. Stryver was a glib man, and an unscrupulous,

972.text:
and a ready, and a bold, he had not that faculty
of extracting the essence from a heap of statements,

979.text:
which is among the most striking and necessary
of the advocate's accomplishments. But, a

986.text:
remarkable improvement came upon him as to
this. The more business he got, the greater

991.text:
his power seemed to grow of getting at its
pith and marrow; and however late at night

997.text:
he sat carousing with Sydney Carton, he always
had his points at his fingers' ends in the

1003.text:
morning.
Sydney Carton, idlest and most unpromising

1008.text:
of men, was Stryver's great ally. What the
two drank together, between Hilary Term and

1014.text:
Michaelmas, might have floated a king's ship.
Stryver never had a case in hand, anywhere,

1021.text:
but Carton was there, with his hands in his
pockets, staring at the ceiling of the court;

1027.text:
they went the same Circuit, and even there
they prolonged their usual orgies late into

1032.text:
the night, and Carton was rumoured to be seen
at broad day, going home stealthily and unsteadily

1038.text:
to his lodgings, like a dissipated cat. At
last, it began to get about, among such as

1045.text:
were interested in the matter, that although
Sydney Carton would never be a lion, he was

1050.text:
an amazingly good jackal, and that he rendered
suit and service to Stryver in that humble

1056.text:
capacity.
"Ten o'clock, sir," said the man at the tavern,

1061.text:
whom he had charged to wake him—"ten o'clock,
sir."

1068.text:
"What do you mean? Ten o'clock at night?"
"Yes, sir. Your honour told me to call you."

1074.text:
"Oh! I remember. Very well, very well."
After a few dull efforts to get to sleep again,

1081.text:
which the man dexterously combated by stirring
the fire continuously for five minutes, he

1087.text:
got up, tossed his hat on, and walked out.
He turned into the Temple, and, having revived

1094.text:
himself by twice pacing the pavements of King's
Bench-walk and Paper-buildings, turned into

1100.text:
the Stryver chambers.
The Stryver clerk, who never assisted at these

1106.text:
conferences, had gone home, and the Stryver
principal opened the door. He had his slippers

1111.text:
on, and a loose bed-gown, and his throat was
bare for his greater ease. He had that rather

1118.text:
wild, strained, seared marking about the eyes,
which may be observed in all free livers of

1124.text:
his class, from the portrait of Jeffries downward,
and which can be traced, under various disguises

1131.text:
of Art, through the portraits of every Drinking
Age.

1135.text:
"You are a little late, Memory," said Stryver.
"About the usual time; it may be a quarter

1143.text:
of an hour later."
They went into a dingy room lined with books

1147.text:
and littered with papers, where there was
a blazing fire. A kettle steamed upon the

1153.text:
hob, and in the midst of the wreck of papers
a table shone, with plenty of wine upon it,

1158.text:
and brandy, and rum, and sugar, and lemons.
"You have had your bottle, I perceive, Sydney."

1166.text:
"Two to-night, I think. I have been dining
with the day's client; or seeing him dine—it's

1171.text:
all one!"
"That was a rare point, Sydney, that you brought

1174.text:
to bear upon the identification. How did you
come by it? When did it strike you?"

1179.text:
"I thought he was rather a handsome fellow,
and I thought I should have been much the

1184.text:
same sort of fellow, if I had had any luck."
Mr. Stryver laughed till he shook his precocious

1191.text:
paunch.
"You and your luck, Sydney! Get to work, get

1195.text:
to work."
Sullenly enough, the jackal loosened his dress,

1201.text:
went into an adjoining room, and came back
with a large jug of cold water, a basin, and

1206.text:
a towel or two. Steeping the towels in the
water, and partially wringing them out, he

1212.text:
folded them on his head in a manner hideous
to behold, sat down at the table, and said,

1218.text:
"Now I am ready!"
"Not much boiling down to be done to-night,

1223.text:
Memory," said Mr. Stryver, gaily, as he looked
among his papers.

1231.text:
"Give me the worst first."
"There they are, Sydney. Fire away!"

1237.text:
The lion then composed himself on his back
on a sofa on one side of the drinking-table,

1243.text:
while the jackal sat at his own paper-bestrewn
table proper, on the other side of it, with

1248.text:
the bottles and glasses ready to his hand.
Both resorted to the drinking-table without

1254.text:
stint, but each in a different way; the lion
for the most part reclining with his hands

1260.text:
in his waistband, looking at the fire, or
occasionally flirting with some lighter document;

1266.text:
the jackal, with knitted brows and intent
face, so deep in his task, that his eyes did

1272.text:
not even follow the hand he stretched out
for his glass—which often groped about,

1277.text:
for a minute or more, before it found the
glass for his lips. Two or three times, the

1282.text:
matter in hand became so knotty, that the
jackal found it imperative on him to get up,

1288.text:
and steep his towels anew. From these pilgrimages
to the jug and basin, he returned with such

1295.text:
eccentricities of damp headgear as no words
can describe; which were made the more ludicrous

1301.text:
by his anxious gravity.
At length the jackal had got together a compact

1307.text:
repast for the lion, and proceeded to offer
it to him. The lion took it with care and

1313.text:
caution, made his selections from it, and
his remarks upon it, and the jackal assisted

1319.text:
both. When the repast was fully discussed,
the lion put his hands in his waistband again,

1326.text:
and lay down to meditate. The jackal then
invigorated himself with a bumper for his

1331.text:
throttle, and a fresh application to his head,
and applied himself to the collection of a

1336.text:
second meal; this was administered to the
lion in the same manner, and was not disposed

1342.text:
of until the clocks struck three in the morning.
"And now we have done, Sydney, fill a bumper

1348.text:
of punch," said Mr. Stryver.
The jackal removed the towels from his head,

1353.text:
which had been steaming again, shook himself,
yawned, shivered, and complied.

1359.text:
"You were very sound, Sydney, in the matter
of those crown witnesses to-day. Every question

1366.text:
told."
"I always am sound; am I not?"

1369.text:
"I don't gainsay it. What has roughened your
temper? Put some punch to it and smooth it

1374.text:
again."
With a deprecatory grunt, the jackal again

1380.text:
complied.
"The old Sydney Carton of old Shrewsbury School,"

1385.text:
said Stryver, nodding his head over him as
he reviewed him in the present and the past,

1390.text:
"the old seesaw Sydney. Up one minute and
down the next; now in spirits and now in despondency!"

1397.text:
"Ah!" returned the other, sighing: "yes! The
same Sydney, with the same luck. Even then,

1405.text:
I did exercises for other boys, and seldom
did my own."

1409.text:
"And why not?"
"God knows. It was my way, I suppose."

1413.text:
He sat, with his hands in his pockets and
his legs stretched out before him, looking

1419.text:
at the fire.
"Carton," said his friend, squaring himself

1424.text:
at him with a bullying air, as if the fire-grate
had been the furnace in which sustained endeavour

1430.text:
was forged, and the one delicate thing to
be done for the old Sydney Carton of old Shrewsbury

1436.text:
School was to shoulder him into it, "your
way is, and always was, a lame way. You summon

1443.text:
no energy and purpose. Look at me."
"Oh, botheration!" returned Sydney, with a

1449.text:
lighter and more good-humoured laugh, "don't
_you_ be moral!"

1453.text:
"How have I done what I have done?" said Stryver;
"how do I do what I do?"

1459.text:
"Partly through paying me to help you, I suppose.
But it's not worth your while to apostrophise

1465.text:
me, or the air, about it; what you want to
do, you do. You were always in the front rank,

1471.text:
and I was always behind."
"I had to get into the front rank; I was not

1476.text:
born there, was I?"
"I was not present at the ceremony; but my

1481.text:
opinion is you were," said Carton. At this,
he laughed again, and they both laughed.

1486.text:
"Before Shrewsbury, and at Shrewsbury, and
ever since Shrewsbury," pursued Carton, "you

1493.text:
have fallen into your rank, and I have fallen
into mine. Even when we were fellow-students

1499.text:
in the Student-Quarter of Paris, picking up
French, and French law, and other French crumbs

1505.text:
that we didn't get much good of, you were
always somewhere, and I was always nowhere."

1510.text:
"And whose fault was that?"
"Upon my soul, I am not sure that it was not

1515.text:
yours. You were always driving and riving
and shouldering and passing, to that restless

1522.text:
degree that I had no chance for my life but
in rust and repose. It's a gloomy thing, however,

1528.text:
to talk about one's own past, with the day
breaking. Turn me in some other direction

horses! Who threw that?"

4732.text:
He looked to the spot where Defarge the vendor
of wine had stood, a moment before; but the

4737.text:
wretched father was grovelling on his face
on the pavement in that spot, and the figure

4743.text:
that stood beside him was the figure of a
dark stout woman, knitting.

4748.text:
"You dogs!" said the Marquis, but smoothly,
and with an unchanged front, except as to

4754.text:
the spots on his nose: "I would ride over
any of you very willingly, and exterminate

4760.text:
you from the earth. If I knew which rascal
threw at the carriage, and if that brigand

4765.text:
were sufficiently near it, he should be crushed
under the wheels."

4770.text:
So cowed was their condition, and so long
and hard their experience of what such a man

4778.text:
could do to them, within the law and beyond
it, that not a voice, or a hand, or even an

4784.text:
eye was raised. Among the men, not one. But
the woman who stood knitting looked up steadily,

4791.text:
and looked the Marquis in the face. It was
not for his dignity to notice it; his contemptuous

4797.text:
eyes passed over her, and over all the other
rats; and he leaned back in his seat again,

4803.text:
and gave the word "Go on!"
He was driven on, and other carriages came

4809.text:
whirling by in quick succession; the Minister,
the State-Projector, the Farmer-General, the

4815.text:
Doctor, the Lawyer, the Ecclesiastic, the
Grand Opera, the Comedy, the whole Fancy Ball

4820.text:
in a bright continuous flow, came whirling
by. The rats had crept out of their holes

4827.text:
to look on, and they remained looking on for
hours; soldiers and police often passing between

4833.text:
them and the spectacle, and making a barrier
behind which they slunk, and through which

4838.text:
they peeped. The father had long ago taken
up his bundle and bidden himself away with

4844.text:
it, when the women who had tended the bundle
while it lay on the base of the fountain,

4849.text:
sat there watching the running of the water
and the rolling of the Fancy Ball—when the

4854.text:
one woman who had stood conspicuous, knitting,
still knitted on with the steadfastness of

4860.text:
Fate. The water of the fountain ran, the swift
river ran, the day ran into evening, so much

4869.text:
life in the city ran into death according
to rule, time and tide waited for no man,

4875.text:
the rats were sleeping close together in their
dark holes again, the Fancy Ball was lighted

4881.text: up at supper, all things ran their course.

4891.text:
Chapter VIII. Monseigneur in the Country
A beautiful landscape, with the corn bright

4897.text:
in it, but not abundant. Patches of poor rye
where corn should have been, patches of poor

4904.text:
peas and beans, patches of most coarse vegetable
substitutes for wheat. On inanimate nature,

4911.text:
as on the men and women who cultivated it,
a prevalent tendency towards an appearance

4916.text:
of vegetating unwillingly—a dejected disposition
to give up, and wither away.

4925.text:
Monsieur the Marquis in his travelling carriage
(which might have been lighter), conducted

4929.text:
by four post-horses and two postilions, fagged
up a steep hill. A blush on the countenance

4936.text:
of Monsieur the Marquis was no impeachment
of his high breeding; it was not from within;

4942.text:
it was occasioned by an external circumstance
beyond his control—the setting sun.

4949.text:
The sunset struck so brilliantly into the
travelling carriage when it gained the hill-top,

4954.text:
that its occupant was steeped in crimson.
"It will die out," said Monsieur the Marquis,

4959.text:
glancing at his hands, "directly."
In effect, the sun was so low that it dipped

4965.text:
at the moment. When the heavy drag had been
adjusted to the wheel, and the carriage slid

4971.text:
down hill, with a cinderous smell, in a cloud
of dust, the red glow departed quickly; the

4978.text:
sun and the Marquis going down together, there
was no glow left when the drag was taken off.

4984.text:
But, there remained a broken country, bold
and open, a little village at the bottom of

4989.text:
the hill, a broad sweep and rise beyond it,
a church-tower, a windmill, a forest for the

4995.text:
chase, and a crag with a fortress on it used
as a prison. Round upon all these darkening

5002.text:
objects as the night drew on, the Marquis
looked, with the air of one who was coming

5008.text:
near home.
The village had its one poor street, with

5012.text:
its poor brewery, poor tannery, poor tavern,
poor stable-yard for relays of post-horses,

5019.text:
poor fountain, all usual poor appointments.
It had its poor people too. All its people

5027.text:
were poor, and many of them were sitting at
their doors, shredding spare onions and the

5032.text:
like for supper, while many were at the fountain,
washing leaves, and grasses, and any such

5038.text:
small yieldings of the earth that could be
eaten. Expressive signs of what made them

5043.text:
poor, were not wanting; the tax for the state,
the tax for the church, the tax for the lord,

5051.text:
tax local and tax general, were to be paid
here and to be paid there, according to solemn

5057.text:
inscription in the little village, until the
wonder was, that there was any village left

5062.text:
unswallowed.
Few children were to be seen, and no dogs.

5068.text:
As to the men and women, their choice on earth
was stated in the prospect—Life on the lowest

5073.text:
terms that could sustain it, down in the little
village under the mill; or captivity and Death

5079.text:
in the dominant prison on the crag.
Heralded by a courier in advance, and by the

5086.text:
cracking of his postilions' whips, which twined
snake-like about their heads in the evening

5092.text:
air, as if he came attended by the Furies,
Monsieur the Marquis drew up in his travelling

5098.text:
carriage at the posting-house gate. It was
hard by the fountain, and the peasants suspended

5105.text:
their operations to look at him. He looked
at them, and saw in them, without knowing

5110.text:
it, the slow sure filing down of misery-worn
face and figure, that was to make the meagreness

5117.text:
of Frenchmen an English superstition which
should survive the truth through the best

5123.text:
part of a hundred years.
Monsieur the Marquis cast his eyes over the

5129.text:
submissive faces that drooped before him,
as the like of himself had drooped before

5134.text:
Monseigneur of the Court—only the difference
was, that these faces drooped merely to suffer

5141.text:
and not to propitiate—when a grizzled mender
of the roads joined the group.

5145.text:
"Bring me hither that fellow!" said the Marquis
to the courier.

5151.text:
The fellow was brought, cap in hand, and the
other fellows closed round to look and listen,

5157.text:
in the manner of the people at the Paris fountain.
"I passed you on the road?"

5163.text:
"Monseigneur, it is true. I had the honour
of being passed on the road."

5168.text:
"Coming up the hill, and at the top of the
hill, both?"

5172.text:
"Monseigneur, it is true."
"What did you look at, so fixedly?"

5179.text:
"Monseigneur, I looked at the man."
He stooped a little, and with his tattered

5185.text:
blue cap pointed under the carriage. All his
fellows stooped to look under the carriage.

5191.text:
"What man, pig? And why look there?"
"Pardon, Monseigneur; he swung by the chain

5198.text:
of the shoe—the drag."
"Who?" demanded the traveller.

5204.text:
"Monseigneur, the man."
"May the Devil carry away these idiots! How

5209.text:
do you call the man? You know all the men
of this part of the country. Who was he?"

5215.text:
"Your clemency, Monseigneur! He was not of
this part of the country. Of all the days

5219.text:
of my life, I never saw him."
"Swinging by the chain? To be suffocated?"

5225.text:
"With your gracious permission, that was the
wonder of it, Monseigneur. His head hanging

5232.text:
over—like this!"
He turned himself sideways to the carriage,

5236.text:
and leaned back, with his face thrown up to
the sky, and his head hanging down; then recovered

5242.text:
himself, fumbled with his cap, and made a
bow.

5246.text:
"What was he like?"
"Monseigneur, he was whiter than the miller.

5251.text:
All covered with dust, white as a spectre,
tall as a spectre!"

5257.text:
The picture produced an immense sensation
in the little crowd; but all eyes, without

5262.text:
comparing notes with other eyes, looked at
Monsieur the Marquis. Perhaps, to observe

5267.text:
whether he had any spectre on his conscience.
"Truly, you did well," said the Marquis, felicitously

5276.text:
sensible that such vermin were not to ruffle
him, "to see a thief accompanying my carriage,

5282.text:
and not open that great mouth of yours. Bah!
Put him aside, Monsieur Gabelle!"

5288.text:
Monsieur Gabelle was the Postmaster, and some
other taxing functionary united; he had come

5294.text:
out with great obsequiousness to assist at
this examination, and had held the examined

5299.text:
by the drapery of his arm in an official manner.
"Bah! Go aside!" said Monsieur Gabelle.

5307.text:
"Lay hands on this stranger if he seeks to
lodge in your village to-night, and be sure

5312.text:
that his business is honest, Gabelle."
"Monseigneur, I am flattered to devote myself

5319.text:
to your orders."
"Did he run away, fellow?—where is that

5324.text:
Accursed?"
The accursed was already under the carriage

5328.text:
with some half-dozen particular friends, pointing
out the chain with his blue cap. Some half-dozen

5334.text:
other particular friends promptly hauled him
out, and presented him breathless to Monsieur

5339.text:
the Marquis.
"Did the man run away, Dolt, when we stopped

5343.text:
for the drag?"
"Monseigneur, he precipitated himself over

5348.text:
the hill-side, head first, as a person plunges
into the river."

5352.text:
"See to it, Gabelle. Go on!"
The half-dozen who were peering at the chain

5358.text:
were still among the wheels, like sheep; the
wheels turned so suddenly that they were lucky

5363.text:
to save their skins and bones; they had very
little else to save, or they might not have

5368.text:
been so fortunate.
The burst with which the carriage started

5372.text:
out of the village and up the rise beyond,
was soon checked by the steepness of the hill.

5377.text:
Gradually, it subsided to a foot pace, swinging
and lumbering upward among the many sweet

5383.text:
scents of a summer night. The postilions,
with a thousand gossamer gnats circling about

5390.text:
them in lieu of the Furies, quietly mended
the points to the lashes of their whips; the

5396.text:
valet walked by the horses; the courier was
audible, trotting on ahead into the dull distance.

5404.text:
At the steepest point of the hill there was
a little burial-ground, with a Cross and a

5409.text:
new large figure of Our Saviour on it; it
was a poor figure in wood, done by some inexperienced

5415.text:
rustic carver, but he had studied the figure
from the life—his own life, maybe—for

5421.text:
it was dreadfully spare and thin.
To this distressful emblem of a great distress

5427.text:
that had long been growing worse, and was
not at its worst, a woman was kneeling. She

5434.text:
turned her head as the carriage came up to
her, rose quickly, and presented herself at

5439.text:
the carriage-door.
"It is you, Monseigneur! Monseigneur, a petition."

5446.text:
With an exclamation of impatience, but with
his unchangeable face, Monseigneur looked

5451.text:
out.
"How, then! What is it? Always petitions!"

5456.text:
"Monseigneur. For the love of the great God!
My husband, the forester."

5462.text:
"What of your husband, the forester? Always
the same with you people. He cannot pay something?"

5467.text:
"He has paid all, Monseigneur. He is dead."
"Well! He is quiet. Can I restore him to you?"

5477.text:
"Alas, no, Monseigneur! But he lies yonder,
under a little heap of poor grass."

5483.text:
"Well?"
"Monseigneur, there are so many little heaps

5492.text:
She looked an old woman, but was young. Her
manner was one of passionate grief; by turns

5498.text:
she clasped her veinous and knotted hands
together with wild energy, and laid one of

5504.text:
them on the carriage-door—tenderly, caressingly,
as if it had been a human breast, and could

5509.text:
be expected to feel the appealing touch.
"Monseigneur, hear me! Monseigneur, hear my

5517.text:
petition! My husband died of want; so many
die of want; so many more will die of want."

5526.text:
"Again, well? Can I feed them?"
"Monseigneur, the good God knows; but I don't

5533.text:
ask it. My petition is, that a morsel of stone
or wood, with my husband's name, may be placed

5540.text:
over him to show where he lies. Otherwise,
the place will be quickly forgotten, it will

5545.text:
never be found when I am dead of the same
malady, I shall be laid under some other heap

5550.text:
of poor grass. Monseigneur, they are so many,
they increase so fast, there is so much want.

5559.text:
Monseigneur! Monseigneur!"
The valet had put her away from the door,

5564.text:
the carriage had broken into a brisk trot,
the postilions had quickened the pace, she

5570.text:
was left far behind, and Monseigneur, again
escorted by the Furies, was rapidly diminishing

5576.text:
the league or two of distance that remained
between him and his chateau.

5582.text:
The sweet scents of the summer night rose
all around him, and rose, as the rain falls,

5588.text:
impartially, on the dusty, ragged, and toil-worn
group at the fountain not far away; to whom

5595.text:
the mender of roads, with the aid of the blue
cap without which he was nothing, still enlarged

5600.text:
upon his man like a spectre, as long as they
could bear it. By degrees, as they could bear

5606.text:
no more, they dropped off one by one, and
lights twinkled in little casements; which

5612.text:
lights, as the casements darkened, and more
stars came out, seemed to have shot up into

5618.text:
the sky instead of having been extinguished.
The shadow of a large high-roofed house, and

5625.text:
of many over-hanging trees, was upon Monsieur
the Marquis by that time; and the shadow was

5631.text:
exchanged for the light of a flambeau, as
his carriage stopped, and the great door of

5636.text:
his chateau was opened to him.
"Monsieur Charles, whom I expect; is he arrived

Chapter IX. The Gorgon's Head
It was a heavy mass of building, that chateau

5660.text:
of Monsieur the Marquis, with a large stone
courtyard before it, and two stone sweeps

5666.text:
of staircase meeting in a stone terrace before
the principal door. A stony business altogether,

5673.text:
with heavy stone balustrades, and stone urns,
and stone flowers, and stone faces of men,

5681.text:
and stone heads of lions, in all directions.
As if the Gorgon's head had surveyed it, when

5687.text:
it was finished, two centuries ago.
Up the broad flight of shallow steps, Monsieur

5693.text:
the Marquis, flambeau preceded, went from
his carriage, sufficiently disturbing the

5699.text:
darkness to elicit loud remonstrance from
an owl in the roof of the great pile of stable

5705.text:
building away among the trees. All else was
so quiet, that the flambeau carried up the

5712.text:
steps, and the other flambeau held at the
great door, burnt as if they were in a close

5718.text:
room of state, instead of being in the open
night-air. Other sound than the owl's voice

5724.text:
there was none, save the falling of a fountain
into its stone basin; for, it was one of those

5730.text:
dark nights that hold their breath by the
hour together, and then heave a long low sigh,

5737.text:
and hold their breath again.
The great door clanged behind him, and Monsieur

5744.text:
the Marquis crossed a hall grim with certain
old boar-spears, swords, and knives of the

5751.text:
chase; grimmer with certain heavy riding-rods
and riding-whips, of which many a peasant,

5758.text:
gone to his benefactor Death, had felt the
weight when his lord was angry.

5763.text:
Avoiding the larger rooms, which were dark
and made fast for the night, Monsieur the

5768.text:
Marquis, with his flambeau-bearer going on
before, went up the staircase to a door in

5774.text:
a corridor. This thrown open, admitted him
to his own private apartment of three rooms:

5781.text:
his bed-chamber and two others. High vaulted
rooms with cool uncarpeted floors, great dogs

5788.text:
upon the hearths for the burning of wood in
winter time, and all luxuries befitting the

5794.text:
state of a marquis in a luxurious age and
country. The fashion of the last Louis but

5802.text:
one, of the line that was never to break—the
fourteenth Louis—was conspicuous in their

5808.text:
rich furniture; but, it was diversified by
many objects that were illustrations of old

5814.text:
pages in the history of France.
A supper-table was laid for two, in the third

5820.text:
of the rooms; a round room, in one of the
chateau's four extinguisher-topped towers.

5826.text:
A small lofty room, with its window wide open,
and the wooden jalousie-blinds closed, so

5833.text:
that the dark night only showed in slight
horizontal lines of black, alternating with

5839.text:
their broad lines of stone colour.
"My nephew," said the Marquis, glancing at

5845.text:
the supper preparation; "they said he was
not arrived."

5850.text:
Nor was he; but, he had been expected with
Monseigneur.

5853.text:
"Ah! It is not probable he will arrive to-night;
nevertheless, leave the table as it is. I

5860.text:
shall be ready in a quarter of an hour."
In a quarter of an hour Monseigneur was ready,

5866.text:
and sat down alone to his sumptuous and choice
supper. His chair was opposite to the window,

5872.text:
and he had taken his soup, and was raising
his glass of Bordeaux to his lips, when he

5877.text:
put it down.
"What is that?" he calmly asked, looking with

5882.text:
attention at the horizontal lines of black
and stone colour.

5887.text:
"Monseigneur? That?"
"Outside the blinds. Open the blinds."

5896.text:
"Monseigneur, it is nothing. The trees and
the night are all that are here."

5902.text:
The servant who spoke, had thrown the blinds
wide, had looked out into the vacant darkness,

5907.text:
and stood with that blank behind him, looking
round for instructions.

5912.text:
"Good," said the imperturbable master. "Close
them again."

5917.text:
That was done too, and the Marquis went on
with his supper. He was half way through it,

5922.text:
when he again stopped with his glass in his
hand, hearing the sound of wheels. It came

5927.text:
on briskly, and came up to the front of the
chateau.

5931.text:
"Ask who is arrived."
It was the nephew of Monseigneur. He had been

5936.text:
some few leagues behind Monseigneur, early
in the afternoon. He had diminished the distance

5942.text:
rapidly, but not so rapidly as to come up
with Monseigneur on the road. He had heard

5947.text:
of Monseigneur, at the posting-houses, as
being before him.

5952.text:
He was to be told (said Monseigneur) that
supper awaited him then and there, and that

5957.text:
he was prayed to come to it. In a little while
he came. He had been known in England as Charles

5963.text:
Darnay.
Monseigneur received him in a courtly manner,

5969.text:
but they did not shake hands.
"You left Paris yesterday, sir?" he said to

5975.text:
Monseigneur, as he took his seat at table.
"Yesterday. And you?"

5982.text:
"Yes."
"You have been a long time coming," said the

5987.text:
Marquis, with a smile.
"On the contrary; I come direct."

5991.text:
"Pardon me! I mean, not a long time on the
journey; a long time intending the journey."

5998.text:
"I have been detained by"—the nephew stopped
a moment in his answer—"various business."

6005.text:
"Without doubt," said the polished uncle.
So long as a servant was present, no other

6011.text:
words passed between them. When coffee had
been served and they were alone together,

6016.text:
the nephew, looking at the uncle and meeting
the eyes of the face that was like a fine

6021.text:
mask, opened a conversation.
"I have come back, sir, as you anticipate,

6027.text:
pursuing the object that took me away. It
carried me into great and unexpected peril;

6033.text:
but it is a sacred object, and if it had carried
me to death I hope it would have sustained

6038.text:
me."
"Not to death," said the uncle; "it is not

6041.text:
necessary to say, to death."
"I doubt, sir," returned the nephew, "whether,

6048.text:
if it had carried me to the utmost brink of
death, you would have cared to stop me there."

6055.text:
The deepened marks in the nose, and the lengthening
of the fine straight lines in the cruel face,

6061.text:
looked ominous as to that; the uncle made
a graceful gesture of protest, which was so

6067.text:
clearly a slight form of good breeding that
it was not reassuring.

6072.text:
"Indeed, sir," pursued the nephew, "for anything
I know, you may have expressly worked to give

6079.text:
a more suspicious appearance to the suspicious
circumstances that surrounded me."

6085.text:
"No, no, no," said the uncle, pleasantly.
"But, however that may be," resumed the nephew,

6092.text:
glancing at him with deep distrust, "I know
that your diplomacy would stop me by any means,

6099.text:
and would know no scruple as to means."
"My friend, I told you so," said the uncle,

6105.text:
with a fine pulsation in the two marks. "Do
me the favour to recall that I told you so,

6114.text:
"Thank you," said the Marquis—very sweetly
indeed.

6118.text:
His tone lingered in the air, almost like
the tone of a musical instrument.

6123.text:
"In effect, sir," pursued the nephew, "I believe
it to be at once your bad fortune, and my

6129.text:
good fortune, that has kept me out of a prison
in France here."

6134.text:
"I do not quite understand," returned the
uncle, sipping his coffee. "Dare I ask you

6140.text:
to explain?"
"I believe that if you were not in disgrace

6145.text:
with the Court, and had not been overshadowed
by that cloud for years past, a letter de

6151.text:
cachet would have sent me to some fortress
indefinitely."

6154.text:
"It is possible," said the uncle, with great
calmness. "For the honour of the family, I

6161.text:
could even resolve to incommode you to that
extent. Pray excuse me!"

6166.text:
"I perceive that, happily for me, the Reception
of the day before yesterday was, as usual,

6173.text:
a cold one," observed the nephew.
"I would not say happily, my friend," returned

6180.text:
the uncle, with refined politeness; "I would
not be sure of that. A good opportunity for

6186.text:
consideration, surrounded by the advantages
of solitude, might influence your destiny

6191.text:
to far greater advantage than you influence
it for yourself. But it is useless to discuss

6197.text:
the question. I am, as you say, at a disadvantage.
These little instruments of correction, these

6203.text:
gentle aids to the power and honour of families,
these slight favours that might so incommode

6209.text:
you, are only to be obtained now by interest
and importunity. They are sought by so many,

6217.text:
and they are granted (comparatively) to so
few! It used not to be so, but France in all

6223.text:
such things is changed for the worse. Our
not remote ancestors held the right of life

6230.text:
and death over the surrounding vulgar. From
this room, many such dogs have been taken

6237.text:
out to be hanged; in the next room (my bedroom),
one fellow, to our knowledge, was poniarded

6243.text:
on the spot for professing some insolent delicacy
respecting his daughter—_his_ daughter?

6249.text:
We have lost many privileges; a new philosophy
has become the mode; and the assertion of

6256.text:
our station, in these days, might (I do not
go so far as to say would, but might) cause

6263.text:
us real inconvenience. All very bad, very
bad!"

6269.text:
The Marquis took a gentle little pinch of
snuff, and shook his head; as elegantly despondent

6275.text:
as he could becomingly be of a country still
containing himself, that great means of regeneration.

6281.text:
"We have so asserted our station, both in
the old time and in the modern time also,"

6288.text:
said the nephew, gloomily, "that I believe
our name to be more detested than any name

6294.text:
in France."
"Let us hope so," said the uncle. "Detestation

6299.text:
of the high is the involuntary homage of the
low."

6304.text:
"There is not," pursued the nephew, in his
former tone, "a face I can look at, in all

6311.text:
this country round about us, which looks at
me with any deference on it but the dark deference

6318.text:

no disrespectful word of that young lady from
any lips; and that if I knew any man—which

9469.text:
I hope I do not—whose taste was so coarse,
and whose temper was so overbearing, that

9475.text:
he could not restrain himself from speaking
disrespectfully of that young lady at this

9481.text:
desk, not even Tellson's should prevent my
giving him a piece of my mind."

9487.text:
The necessity of being angry in a suppressed
tone had put Mr. Stryver's blood-vessels into

9493.text:
a dangerous state when it was his turn to
be angry; Mr. Lorry's veins, methodical as

9499.text:
their courses could usually be, were in no
better state now it was his turn.

9505.text:
"That is what I mean to tell you, sir," said
Mr. Lorry. "Pray let there be no mistake about

9511.text:
it."
Mr. Stryver sucked the end of a ruler for

9515.text:
a little while, and then stood hitting a tune
out of his teeth with it, which probably gave

9520.text:
him the toothache. He broke the awkward silence
by saying:

9524.text:
"This is something new to me, Mr. Lorry. You
deliberately advise me not to go up to Soho

9531.text:
and offer myself—_my_self, Stryver of the
King's Bench bar?"

9536.text:
"Do you ask me for my advice, Mr. Stryver?"
"Yes, I do."

9540.text:
"Very good. Then I give it, and you have repeated
it correctly."

9544.text:
"And all I can say of it is," laughed Stryver
with a vexed laugh, "that this—ha, ha!—beats

9550.text:
everything past, present, and to come."
"Now understand me," pursued Mr. Lorry. "As

9557.text:
a man of business, I am not justified in saying
anything about this matter, for, as a man

9562.text:
of business, I know nothing of it. But, as
an old fellow, who has carried Miss Manette

9568.text:
in his arms, who is the trusted friend of
Miss Manette and of her father too, and who

9573.text:
has a great affection for them both, I have
spoken. The confidence is not of my seeking,

9579.text:
recollect. Now, you think I may not be right?"
"Not I!" said Stryver, whistling. "I can't

9585.text:
undertake to find third parties in common
sense; I can only find it for myself. I suppose

9591.text:
sense in certain quarters; you suppose mincing
bread-and-butter nonsense. It's new to me,

9598.text:
but you are right, I dare say."
"What I suppose, Mr. Stryver, I claim to characterise

9604.text:
for myself—And understand me, sir," said
Mr. Lorry, quickly flushing again, "I will

9610.text:
not—not even at Tellson's—have it characterised
for me by any gentleman breathing."

9616.text:
"There! I beg your pardon!" said Stryver.
"Granted. Thank you. Well, Mr. Stryver, I

9623.text:
was about to say:—it might be painful to
you to find yourself mistaken, it might be

9629.text:
painful to Doctor Manette to have the task
of being explicit with you, it might be very

9635.text:
painful to Miss Manette to have the task of
being explicit with you. You know the terms

9640.text:
upon which I have the honour and happiness
to stand with the family. If you please, committing

9645.text:
you in no way, representing you in no way,
I will undertake to correct my advice by the

9651.text:
exercise of a little new observation and judgment
expressly brought to bear upon it. If you

9657.text:
should then be dissatisfied with it, you can
but test its soundness for yourself; if, on

9664.text:
the other hand, you should be satisfied with
it, and it should be what it now is, it may

9669.text:
spare all sides what is best spared. What
do you say?"

9673.text:
"How long would you keep me in town?"
"Oh! It is only a question of a few hours.

9679.text:
I could go to Soho in the evening, and come
to your chambers afterwards."

9683.text:
"Then I say yes," said Stryver: "I won't go
up there now, I am not so hot upon it as that

9689.text:
comes to; I say yes, and I shall expect you
to look in to-night. Good morning."

9695.text:
Then Mr. Stryver turned and burst out of the
Bank, causing such a concussion of air on

9701.text:
his passage through, that to stand up against
it bowing behind the two counters, required

9707.text:
the utmost remaining strength of the two ancient
clerks. Those venerable and feeble persons

9713.text:
were always seen by the public in the act
of bowing, and were popularly believed, when

9719.text:
they had bowed a customer out, still to keep
on bowing in the empty office until they bowed

9724.text:
another customer in.
The barrister was keen enough to divine that

9729.text:
the banker would not have gone so far in his
expression of opinion on any less solid ground

9735.text:
than moral certainty. Unprepared as he was
for the large pill he had to swallow, he got

9741.text:
it down. "And now," said Mr. Stryver, shaking
his forensic forefinger at the Temple in general,

9749.text:
when it was down, "my way out of this, is,
to put you all in the wrong."

9757.text:
It was a bit of the art of an Old Bailey tactician,
in which he found great relief. "You shall

9763.text:
not put me in the wrong, young lady," said
Mr. Stryver; "I'll do that for you."

9769.text:
Accordingly, when Mr. Lorry called that night
as late as ten o'clock, Mr. Stryver, among

9774.text:
a quantity of books and papers littered out
for the purpose, seemed to have nothing less

9780.text:
on his mind than the subject of the morning.
He even showed surprise when he saw Mr. Lorry,

9785.text:
and was altogether in an absent and preoccupied
state.

9788.text:
"Well!" said that good-natured emissary, after
a full half-hour of bootless attempts to bring

9795.text:
him round to the question. "I have been to
Soho."

9798.text:
"To Soho?" repeated Mr. Stryver, coldly. "Oh,
to be sure! What am I thinking of!"

9805.text:
"And I have no doubt," said Mr. Lorry, "that
I was right in the conversation we had. My

9811.text:
opinion is confirmed, and I reiterate my advice."
"I assure you," returned Mr. Stryver, in the

9818.text:
friendliest way, "that I am sorry for it on
your account, and sorry for it on the poor

9823.text:
father's account. I know this must always
be a sore subject with the family; let us

9828.text:
say no more about it."
"I don't understand you," said Mr. Lorry.

9833.text:
"I dare say not," rejoined Stryver, nodding
his head in a smoothing and final way; "no

9840.text:
matter, no matter."
"But it does matter," Mr. Lorry urged.

9844.text:
"No it doesn't; I assure you it doesn't. Having
supposed that there was sense where there

9851.text:
is no sense, and a laudable ambition where
there is not a laudable ambition, I am well

9857.text:
out of my mistake, and no harm is done. Young
women have committed similar follies often

9864.text:
before, and have repented them in poverty
and obscurity often before. In an unselfish

9871.text:
aspect, I am sorry that the thing is dropped,
because it would have been a bad thing for

9876.text:
me in a worldly point of view; in a selfish
aspect, I am glad that the thing has dropped,

9882.text:
because it would have been a bad thing for
me in a worldly point of view—it is hardly

9885.text:
necessary to say I could have gained nothing
by it. There is no harm at all done. I have

9891.text:
not proposed to the young lady, and, between
ourselves, I am by no means certain, on reflection,

9897.text:
that I ever should have committed myself to
that extent. Mr. Lorry, you cannot control

9903.text:
the mincing vanities and giddinesses of empty-headed
girls; you must not expect to do it, or you

9908.text:
will always be disappointed. Now, pray say
no more about it. I tell you, I regret it

9914.text:
on account of others, but I am satisfied on
my own account. And I am really very much

9920.text:
obliged to you for allowing me to sound you,
and for giving me your advice; you know the

9925.text:
young lady better than I do; you were right,
it never would have done."

9930.text:
Mr. Lorry was so taken aback, that he looked
quite stupidly at Mr. Stryver shouldering

9935.text:
him towards the door, with an appearance of
showering generosity, forbearance, and goodwill,

9942.text:
on his erring head. "Make the best of it,
my dear sir," said Stryver; "say no more about

9948.text:
it; thank you again for allowing me to sound
you; good night!"

9953.text:
Mr. Lorry was out in the night, before he
knew where he was. Mr. Stryver was lying back

9958.text: on his sofa, winking at his ceiling.

9968.text:
Chapter XIII. The Fellow of No Delicacy
If Sydney Carton ever shone anywhere, he certainly

9975.text:
never shone in the house of Doctor Manette.
He had been there often, during a whole year,

9980.text:
and had always been the same moody and morose
lounger there. When he cared to talk, he talked

9986.text:
well; but, the cloud of caring for nothing,
which overshadowed him with such a fatal darkness,

9992.text:
was very rarely pierced by the light within
him.

9997.text:
And yet he did care something for the streets
that environed that house, and for the senseless

10002.text:
stones that made their pavements. Many a night
he vaguely and unhappily wandered there, when

10008.text:
wine had brought no transitory gladness to
him; many a dreary daybreak revealed his solitary

10015.text:
figure lingering there, and still lingering
there when the first beams of the sun brought

10021.text:
into strong relief, removed beauties of architecture
in spires of churches and lofty buildings,

10027.text:
as perhaps the quiet time brought some sense
of better things, else forgotten and unattainable,

10034.text:
into his mind. Of late, the neglected bed
in the Temple Court had known him more scantily

10041.text:
than ever; and often when he had thrown himself
upon it no longer than a few minutes, he had

10047.text:
got up again, and haunted that neighbourhood.
On a day in August, when Mr. Stryver (after

10054.text:
notifying to his jackal that "he had thought
better of that marrying matter") had carried

10059.text:
his delicacy into Devonshire, and when the
sight and scent of flowers in the City streets

10065.text:
had some waifs of goodness in them for the
worst, of health for the sickliest, and of

10071.text:
youth for the oldest, Sydney's feet still
trod those stones. From being irresolute and

10077.text:
purposeless, his feet became animated by an
intention, and, in the working out of that

10083.text:
intention, they took him to the Doctor's door.
He was shown up-stairs, and found Lucie at

10090.text:
her work, alone. She had never been quite
at her ease with him, and received him with

10095.text:
some little embarrassment as he seated himself
near her table. But, looking up at his face

10102.text:
in the interchange of the first few common-places,
she observed a change in it.

10106.text:
"I fear you are not well, Mr. Carton!"
"No. But the life I lead, Miss Manette, is

10113.text:
not conducive to health. What is to be expected
of, or by, such profligates?"

10118.text:
"Is it not—forgive me; I have begun the
question on my lips—a pity to live no better

10125.text:
life?"
"God knows it is a shame!"

10129.text:
"Then why not change it?"
Looking gently at him again, she was surprised

10134.text:
and saddened to see that there were tears
in his eyes. There were tears in his voice

10139.text:
too, as he answered:
"It is too late for that. I shall never be

10144.text:
better than I am. I shall sink lower, and
be worse."

10149.text:
He leaned an elbow on her table, and covered
his eyes with his hand. The table trembled

10155.text:
in the silence that followed.
She had never seen him softened, and was much

10160.text:
distressed. He knew her to be so, without
looking at her, and said:

10165.text:
"Pray forgive me, Miss Manette. I break down
before the knowledge of what I want to say

10170.text:
to you. Will you hear me?"
"If it will do you any good, Mr. Carton, if

10174.text:
it would make you happier, it would make me
very glad!"

10177.text:
"God bless you for your sweet compassion!"
He unshaded his face after a little while,

10184.text:
and spoke steadily.
"Don't be afraid to hear me. Don't shrink

10188.text:
from anything I say. I am like one who died
young. All my life might have been."

10195.text:
"No, Mr. Carton. I am sure that the best part
of it might still be; I am sure that you might

10200.text:
be much, much worthier of yourself."
"Say of you, Miss Manette, and although I

10206.text:
know better—although in the mystery of my
own wretched heart I know better—I shall

10211.text:
never forget it!"
She was pale and trembling. He came to her

10216.text:
relief with a fixed despair of himself which
made the interview unlike any other that could

10222.text:
have been holden.
"If it had been possible, Miss Manette, that

10226.text:
you could have returned the love of the man
you see before yourself—flung away, wasted,

10232.text:
drunken, poor creature of misuse as you know
him to be—he would have been conscious this

10238.text:
day and hour, in spite of his happiness, that
he would bring you to misery, bring you to

10243.text:
sorrow and repentance, blight you, disgrace
you, pull you down with him. I know very well

10250.text:
that you can have no tenderness for me; I
ask for none; I am even thankful that it cannot

10256.text:
be."
"Without it, can I not save you, Mr. Carton?

10261.text:
Can I not recall you—forgive me again!—to
a better course? Can I in no way repay your

10267.text:
confidence? I know this is a confidence,"
she modestly said, after a little hesitation,

10272.text:
and in earnest tears, "I know you would say
this to no one else. Can I turn it to no good

10277.text:
account for yourself, Mr. Carton?"
He shook his head.

10282.text:
"To none. No, Miss Manette, to none. If you
will hear me through a very little more, all

10289.text:
you can ever do for me is done. I wish you
to know that you have been the last dream

10295.text:
of my soul. In my degradation I have not been
so degraded but that the sight of you with

10301.text:
your father, and of this home made such a
home by you, has stirred old shadows that

10307.text:
I thought had died out of me. Since I knew
you, I have been troubled by a remorse that

10313.text:
I thought would never reproach me again, and
have heard whispers from old voices impelling

10319.text:
me upward, that I thought were silent for
ever. I have had unformed ideas of striving

10325.text:
afresh, beginning anew, shaking off sloth
and sensuality, and fighting out the abandoned

10332.text:
fight. A dream, all a dream, that ends in
nothing, and leaves the sleeper where he lay

10337.text:
down, but I wish you to know that you inspired
it."

10342.text:
"Will nothing of it remain? O Mr. Carton,
think again! Try again!"

10348.text:
"No, Miss Manette; all through it, I have
known myself to be quite undeserving. And

10354.text:
yet I have had the weakness, and have still
the weakness, to wish you to know with what

10359.text:
a sudden mastery you kindled me, heap of ashes
that I am, into fire—a fire, however, inseparable

10367.text:
in its nature from myself, quickening nothing,
lighting nothing, doing no service, idly burning

10375.text:
away."
"Since it is my misfortune, Mr. Carton, to

10379.text:
have made you more unhappy than you were before
you knew me—"

10383.text:
"Don't say that, Miss Manette, for you would
have reclaimed me, if anything could. You

10388.text:
will not be the cause of my becoming worse."
"Since the state of your mind that you describe,

10393.text:
is, at all events, attributable to some influence
of mine—this is what I mean, if I can make

10400.text:
it plain—can I use no influence to serve
you? Have I no power for good, with you, at

10407.text:
all?"
"The utmost good that I am capable of now,

10411.text:
Miss Manette, I have come here to realise.
Let me carry through the rest of my misdirected

10417.text:
life, the remembrance that I opened my heart
to you, last of all the world; and that there

10423.text:
was something left in me at this time which
you could deplore and pity."

10427.text:
"Which I entreated you to believe, again and
again, most fervently, with all my heart,

10433.text:
was capable of better things, Mr. Carton!"
"Entreat me to believe it no more, Miss Manette.

10439.text:
I have proved myself, and I know better. I
distress you; I draw fast to an end. Will

10446.text:
you let me believe, when I recall this day,
that the last confidence of my life was reposed

10452.text:
in your pure and innocent breast, and that
it lies there alone, and will be shared by

10458.text:
no one?"
"If that will be a consolation to you, yes."

10463.text:
"Not even by the dearest one ever to be known
to you?"

10467.text:
"Mr. Carton," she answered, after an agitated
pause, "the secret is yours, not mine; and

10474.text:
I promise to respect it."
"Thank you. And again, God bless you."

10481.text:
He put her hand to his lips, and moved towards
the door.

10484.text:
"Be under no apprehension, Miss Manette, of
my ever resuming this conversation by so much

10490.text:
as a passing word. I will never refer to it
again. If I were dead, that could not be surer

10497.text:
than it is henceforth. In the hour of my death,
I shall hold sacred the one good remembrance—and

10502.text:
shall thank and bless you for it—that my
last avowal of myself was made to you, and

10509.text:
that my name, and faults, and miseries were
gently carried in your heart. May it otherwise

10515.text:
be light and happy!"
He was so unlike what he had ever shown himself

10521.text:
to be, and it was so sad to think how much
he had thrown away, and how much he every

10527.text:
day kept down and perverted, that Lucie Manette
wept mournfully for him as he stood looking

10533.text:
back at her.
"Be comforted!" he said, "I am not worth such

10537.text:
feeling, Miss Manette. An hour or two hence,
and the low companions and low habits that

10543.text:
I scorn but yield to, will render me less
worth such tears as those, than any wretch

10549.text:
who creeps along the streets. Be comforted!
But, within myself, I shall always be, towards

10556.text:
you, what I am now, though outwardly I shall
be what you have heretofore seen me. The last

10562.text:
supplication but one I make to you, is, that
you will believe this of me."

10567.text:
"I will, Mr. Carton."
"My last supplication of all, is this; and

10573.text:
with it, I will relieve you of a visitor with
whom I well know you have nothing in unison,

10578.text:
and between whom and you there is an impassable
space. It is useless to say it, I know, but

10585.text:
it rises out of my soul. For you, and for
any dear to you, I would do anything. If my

10591.text:
career were of that better kind that there
was any opportunity or capacity of sacrifice

10597.text:
in it, I would embrace any sacrifice for you
and for those dear to you. Try to hold me

10603.text:
in your mind, at some quiet times, as ardent
and sincere in this one thing. The time will

10610.text:
come, the time will not be long in coming,
when new ties will be formed about you—ties

10615.text:
that will bind you yet more tenderly and strongly
to the home you so adorn—the dearest ties

10622.text:
that will ever grace and gladden you. O Miss
Manette, when the little picture of a happy

10628.text:
father's face looks up in yours, when you
see your own bright beauty springing up anew

10633.text:
at your feet, think now and then that there
is a man who would give his life, to keep

10640.text:
a life you love beside you!"
